Description: Inlay-eye: made from moulded white glass with blue glass rims and an obsidian pupil. The tear duct is carefully delineated; the broken outer end was originally almost certainly extended to represent a cosmetic line.
Findspot: Found/Acquired: Egypt, Possibly San el-Hagar, low tell on the south of San (Petrie)
Curator's comments: Pair with inlay-eye (1885,0101.211). Although stylized such inlays were used to give three-dimensional Egyptian work a vital, living appearance. These pieces were almost certainly inlaid into the head of an anthropoid (human form) coffin or a mummy mask of the kind worn by Tutankhamun. Bibliography: 'Egyptian Treasures' [exhibition catalogue] (Shanghai, 1999): 186-187 No 56; See C. Favard-Meeks in P. Brissaud & C. Zivie-Coche (eds), 'Tanis : travaux récents sur le tell Sân el-Hagar : Mission française des fouilles de Tanis, 1987-1997' (1998), p.118.
Bibliographic references: Andrews 2000 / Egyptian Treasures from the British Museum (p.146-147)
